info.title: Preparing firmware for NVIDIA Jetson platforms

abstract.para: UEFI system firmware allows SUSE Linux media and installations to boot.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: SUSE Linux installation media are formatted as UEFI Removable Media and require Arm* SystemReady compliant boot firmware on the system.

info.title: Installing kernel modules for NVIDIA Jetson platforms

abstract.para: A Kernel Module Package (KMP) provides additional kernel drivers.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: SUSE Linux products contain drivers to boot on NVIDIA* Orin* and earlier NVIDIA Jetson* platforms. But as documented in the Release Notes, certain drivers are not included.
NVIDIA JetPack* SDK 6.0 and its Jetson Linux Driver Pack 36.3 and later releases provide additional kernel driver modules in source form.

section.title: Requirements

listitem.para: NVIDIA Jetson Orin System-on-Module
SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP6

section.para: NVIDIA Jetson Xavier* and earlier System-on-Module generations are no longer supported in NVIDIA JetPack SDK 6.0 and later releases.

section.title: Installing the drivers
section.para: Install third-party kernel drivers provided via SUSE SolidDriver Program.

procedure.para: Perform the following steps on your NVIDIA based system.

step.para: Add the repositories for the Kernel Module Package:
Check whether kernel flavor default or 64kb is used:
Install the KMP for that same kernel flavor:

note.para: Installing nvidia-jetson-kmp-default will by default also install nvidia-jetson-extra-kmp-default with further drivers beyond the GPU.

section.title: Summary
section.para: You have installed third-party kernel driver modules on your system and rebooted it for them to get loaded.
However, these drivers are not supported by the SUSE provided Mesa graphics libraries or Xorg modules and instead require to install proprietary third-party libraries.

section.title: Troubleshooting
section.para: If the kernel modules are not probed at all, verify that you installed the right flavor.
If the kernel modules are not probed successfully (in dmesg), verify that your system is based on NVIDIA Orin chipset and that no conflicting NVIDIA drivers for discrete GPUs are installed.
Linux kernel driver modules like these cannot provide a kernel console. You will still need to use the serial console, same as before.

info.title: Installing NVIDIA libraries for NVIDIA Jetson platforms

abstract.para: NVIDIA* libraries consume the NVIDIA Jetson* graphics drivers.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: To exploit the NVIDIA Orin* GPU and DLA, third-party kernel drivers and libraries are needed.
The SLES NVIDIA Compute Module does not offer RPM packages for NVIDIA Jetson's integrated GPU today. As alternative we explain how to install the correct NVIDIA provided downloads for SUSE systems.
